values.alignmentText: Egypt offers desert landscapes, the Nile, and Red Sea reefs, but rapid urbanization around Cairo contributes to pollution and habitat loss.
Water scarcity, Nile Delta erosion, and extreme heat waves make climate change a major concern for long-term livability.
Egypt features hot, dry summers and mild winters with minimal rain; sandstorms occasionally disrupt spring.
Cairo regularly records PM2.5 levels above 50 µg/m³ due to traffic and agricultural burning, necessitating air purifiers for the kids.
The country faces low seismic activity but is exposed to flash floods in Sinai and coastal storm surges in Alexandria.
March–May in Cairo brings 15–30°C (59–86°F) with occasional khamsin winds raising dust and temperatures.
June–August temperatures soar to 35–40°C (95–104°F) with intense sun, challenging Sarah’s mild-weather preference.
Autumn cools to 20–30°C (68–86°F) with less dust, offering more comfortable outdoor time.
December–February days stay 12–20°C (54–68°F) with chilly evenings, aligning better with the family’s desired climate.
Resorts along the Red Sea (Hurghada, Sharm El Sheikh) deliver warm water, snorkeling, and family resorts, though travel from Cairo takes planning.
Red Sea temperatures range 22–28°C (72–82°F) year-round, while Mediterranean beaches cool to 18°C (64°F) in winter.
Desert oases, ancient sites, and coral reefs offer dramatic scenery, but environmental degradation threatens parts of the Nile and reefs.
Public sector minimum wage recently rose to EGP 3,500/month (~$113), far below costs for middle-class lifestyles.
Senior developers in Cairo earn EGP 300k–450k/year (~$9.7–14.5k), making remote or freelance USD income far more attractive for Trey and Sarah.
Large banks, telecoms, and outsourcing firms use .NET stacks, but projects often focus on legacy enterprise work with conservative cultures.
Ruby jobs are rare; most startups favor PHP, JavaScript, or Java, so Sarah would rely on remote contracts.
Companies rarely sponsor Western employees; work permits require local labor market tests and heavy documentation.
The economy is growing but faces high inflation, currency devaluations, and heavy debt, creating financial volatility.
Tech firms adopted hybrid work during the pandemic, yet power outages and inconsistent internet outside premium neighborhoods hinder seamless remote work.
Corporate culture often expects long hours and rigid hierarchies, limiting Sarah’s desired work-life separation.
The legal workweek is 48 hours; many companies expect six-day weeks or overtime during peak projects.
Employees earn 21 days after a year, increasing with tenure, alongside numerous religious and national holidays.
Private firms often provide the legal minimum; approvals can be subject to managerial discretion.
Cairo’s bustle, traffic, and bureaucracy create a fast-paced daily rhythm, though neighborhoods like Maadi feel slower.
Schools start around 8 a.m., offices 9 a.m., with long commutes and late dinners influenced by evening social visits.
Weekends (Friday-Saturday) revolve around family lunches, mosque visits, and Nile or desert day trips, offering cultural immersion.
Family bonds are strong and neighbors often help each other, but privacy expectations differ from the US.
Polyamory conflicts with legal and social norms; Egypt criminalizes adultery and promotes conservative family structures.
Parents emphasize respect, academic achievement, and religious values, with schools expecting disciplined behavior.
Gated communities and international schools offer safe spaces, but public parks and pedestrian infrastructure are limited.
International schools (American, British, IB) in Cairo and Alexandria provide high-quality options at premium fees; public schools suffer overcrowding.
Private nurseries and nannies are common in affluent areas, while public early childhood programs are scarce.
Extended families and informal caregivers provide most support; state subsidies are minimal.
Expat families rely on nannies or daycare within international schools, requiring vetting and language coordination.
Public education is free but quality varies widely, leading middle-class families to seek private or language schools.
International schools accept foreigners but have waiting lists and high tuition, requiring early planning.
International and national private schools offer rigorous academics and bilingual programs but demand significant tuition and entrance exams.
Maternity leave provides 90 days at partial pay and public childcare support is limited, pushing families toward private solutions.
Foreign workers depend on employer policies for leave; legal entitlements are not guaranteed for expats.
Public universities like Cairo University offer affordable degrees, while private universities cater to affluent students.
Foreign students can enroll with tuition rates higher than locals; programs are mostly Arabic or English depending on institution.
Traditional gender roles persist, though urban women increasingly work and pursue higher education; societal expectations remain conservative.
Legal recognition for transgender people is limited and social acceptance is very low, posing significant challenges for gender-diverse individuals.
Women face legal inequalities in family law and limited protections against harassment despite recent reforms.
Modest dress and traditional femininity are expected in many contexts, though cosmopolitan enclaves allow more flexibility.
Men are expected to be providers and authority figures; emotional openness is less common but changing among younger professionals.
Pharaonic history, Islamic architecture, and desert exploration offer unique creative inspiration for Trey’s projects.
Arabic is essential for daily life; English is spoken in tourism, international schools, and some tech firms but not in bureaucracy.
Progressive communities exist online and in art scenes, yet national politics remain conservative with tight limits on dissent.
Socialist ideals influenced past policy, but current attitudes favor state-led capitalism with limited space for leftist organizing.
Atheism is legal but socially frowned upon; open secularism is safest within expat or intellectual circles.
Sexual topics remain private and conservative; non-traditional relationships face social and legal risks.
LGBTQ+ individuals face harassment and periodic crackdowns, with no legal protections in place.
Egyptians are hospitable and community-oriented, often inviting newcomers for meals and celebrations.
National identity draws pride from ancient heritage and regional leadership, despite economic challenges.
Relations range from cooperative with Gulf allies to tense with Ethiopia over the Nile dam, shaping public discourse.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Neighbors see Egypt as a cultural powerhouse with outsized political influence, yet sometimes criticize domestic repression.
Cairo offers cafes, Nile cruises, and lounges, but alcohol regulations and conservative norms create more subdued nightlife than in Europe.
Men blend Western business attire with traditional galabeyas; lightweight fabrics help manage desert heat.
Women mix modest fashion, hijabs, and Western styles depending on social context, offering Sarah expressive yet respectful choices.
Families enjoy café culture, football, desert camping, and Red Sea diving, providing varied weekend options.
Board-game cafes like Qahwa Mazaj in Cairo host events, though import costs limit selection compared with Europe.
Live music blends Arabic pop, jazz, and electronic nights; events often start late and cater to cosmopolitan crowds.
Tech meetups, maker spaces, and cultural clubs exist in Cairo, offering Trey and Sarah networking despite bureaucratic hurdles.
Weekend trips to Fayoum, Sinai hikes, or Red Sea diving are reachable but require planning and sometimes security permissions.
Egypt is a presidential republic with limited opposition and strong military influence over governance.
Islam heavily informs law and policy; the state manages religious institutions while promoting conservative social norms.
Labor unions have limited independence, and worker protections are weak, especially for informal sectors.
The government espouses national development, security, and stability with a top-down approach to modernization.
Civil liberties have tightened significantly since 2013, with restrictions on protests, media, and NGOs.
A state-led economy with military-owned enterprises coexists with private investment, creating uneven competition.
Security apparatus maintains order and large protests are rare, but economic shocks and currency devaluations create uncertainty.
State-aligned media dominates television and emphasizes government achievements, limiting dissenting narratives.
Messaging highlights national security, mega-projects, and patriotism, which may feel heavy-handed for the family’s pluralistic tastes.
Programs like Takaful and Karama provide cash transfers, yet broader social safety nets are limited and bureaucracy is heavy.
Many citizens support the government for stability, but inflation and civil liberty concerns erode trust among urban professionals.
Petty corruption and opaque procurement persist, particularly in licensing and customs processes.
Facilitation payments and patronage networks are common, especially when dealing with permits or customs.
Gated communities in New Cairo and 6th of October City offer modern housing with amenities, while older districts face infrastructure strain.
Violent crime is relatively low, but sexual harassment, petty theft, and traffic accidents require vigilance, especially for Sarah.
Public hospitals struggle with overcrowding and limited equipment; wealthier Egyptians rely on private clinics.
Private hospitals like Cleopatra and As-Salam provide quality care with English-speaking staff, though specialized treatment may require travel.
Nannies and domestic helpers are affordable, but training and employment contracts require attentive management.
Families build support networks through relatives and private services, balancing hospitality with bureaucratic hurdles.
International schools deliver strong academics, but public education quality gaps and rote learning require active parental involvement.
Cairo’s metro and new monorail projects improve mobility, yet overcrowding and limited coverage make cars or ride-hailing necessary for families.
Egypt pursues state-led development with mega-projects and incentives for foreign investment, offering opportunities alongside red tape.
Tax filing is centralized but documentation-heavy; VAT and income tax compliance usually requires a local accountant.
Top marginal income tax reaches 25% plus social contributions; foreigners become tax residents after 183 days unless structured otherwise.
Opening bank accounts requires residency visas and letters; cash remains common, though mobile wallets like InstaPay are growing.
Everyday costs are lower than the US, but inflation and imported goods raise budgets; international schooling and travel add premiums.
Public pensions offer limited income, encouraging supplemental savings or reliance on family support.
Foreigners typically maintain overseas retirement accounts; there is no dedicated retiree visa offering tax incentives.
Employment, investor, and property-owner visas exist but involve extensive paperwork; long-term residency is difficult without employer sponsorship.
Egyptians welcome American tourists and educators, yet immigration systems are geared toward regional workers, not US families.
Work visas renew annually; investor residency requires significant capital, and long-term permits remain discretionary.
Citizenship through residency is rare; investors can apply after a large deposit, but dual citizenship may require approvals.
Dependents can join on residence permits, but spousal work rights require separate approvals and employers.
Permits involve multiple ministry visits, security checks, and translation fees, often taking several months.
Visa overstays incur fines; security checks and sudden policy shifts demand close tracking of paperwork and exit requirements.
Egypt allows dual citizenship with permission, but applicants must notify authorities and may face military service considerations.
Residency requires police clearances, notarized leases, and occasional security interviews; legal counsel smooths the process.
A small yet growing game dev scene clusters around Cairo startups focused on mobile and educational products.

As noted in Game Dev Work Prospects, A small yet growing game dev scene clusters around Cairo startups focused on mobile and educational products. Hiring velocity at established studios in Egypt is slow, with hiring cycles stretching several months or pausing until budgets free up.

Compensation trails larger hubs, so candidates leverage remote offers or equity to bridge gaps. When opportunities surface in Egypt, established studios benchmark offers against peers across the ecosystem.
Established studios in Egypt rely on English for cross-border collaboration, while local-language fluency remains important for community, compliance, and platform partnerships.
Remote expectations at established studios in Egypt favor on-site work, offering limited hybrid options outside key leadership roles.
Studios like Instinct Games, Rumbling Games, and Semaphore Lab operate locally, often collaborating with international partners.
Cairo Game Jam, Gamers Lounge, and university clubs host events, providing Trey with networking channels despite a modest scene.
Government innovation funds exist but focus on fintech; game startups rely on self-funding and regional publishers, increasing risk.

Startup founders report that Government innovation funds exist but focus on fintech; game startups rely on self-funding and regional publishers, increasing risk. Hiring velocity at early-stage studios in Egypt is slow, with hiring cycles stretching several months or pausing until budgets free up.
Compensation trails larger hubs, so candidates leverage remote offers or equity to bridge gaps. Early teams in Egypt balance cash and equity to stay competitive while managing runway.
Founding teams in Egypt lean on English for investor and platform communication, while local-language fluency helps with hiring, compliance, and community outreach.
Remote expectations among startups in Egypt favor on-site work, offering limited hybrid options outside key leadership roles.
New Cairo districts feature modern malls, fiber internet, and expanding transit, yet power cuts and traffic persist in older neighborhoods.
Every season brings common extremes, so we rely on specialized clothing, cooling, or heating solutions to stay comfortable.
Major daylight imbalances demand heavy interventions—SAD lamps, vitamin regimens, and frequent travel for sun exposure.
Pleasant stretches appear sporadically, so spontaneous outdoor plans are rare and weather dominates scheduling.
Survival dominates—frequent trade-offs between rent, food, and healthcare with minimal institutional help.
Lifestyle feels brittle; one unexpected expense forces significant cutbacks or debt.
Affluent households encounter noticeable friction—specialists, tutors, or clubs are scarce or highly gated.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: Most 2k sq ft options feel overpriced or stuck in fringe neighborhoods with weaker schools.
Intentional communities exist but are limited in size or geared toward niche demographics.
Friendliness varies by neighborhood; we can cultivate ties but must invest time and select communities carefully.
Negative media framing and policy tightenings create a defensive posture for newcomers.
Suspicion around privilege is common, demanding constant humility and proof of local investment.
Interactions can be efficient yet emotionally flat; kindness takes effort to elicit.
Many acquaintances stay casual, but dedicated outreach unlocks close friendships over time.
Personal space is often compressed, so we must advocate gently for comfort.
Honesty is situational; locals may avoid uncomfortable topics entirely.
Beauty investments run high; opting out draws comments or limits opportunities.
Body shaming is common and influences opportunities or friendships.
Trend cycles move fast; failing to keep up draws comments or limits networking.
Victim-blaming attitudes persist, eroding trust in institutions.
Communities enforce strict gendered behavior with little tolerance for experimentation.
Negative narratives dominate; openness threatens custody, employment, or housing. non-monogamy acceptance.
Conservative norms dominate; promiscuity is equated with poor character.
Multi-partner households face outright hostility or legal barriers.
Culture favors close contact; sensory-sensitive family members often feel overwhelmed.
High prevalence of firearms and lax rules elevate daily risk perception.
Harsh sentencing and moral panic dominate political rhetoric.
Families risk collateral trauma from militarized raids or wrongful accusations.
Incidents happen with disturbing frequency, shaping daily routines and mental load.
Conditions are degrading with widespread labor exploitation and violence.
Walking is possible yet stressful due to gaps in sidewalks or aggressive driving.
Community norms lean unhealthy, making it hard to model good habits for kids.
Maintaining clean eating requires vigilance and possibly specialty stores.
Fresh options exist yet international diversity is limited to a few neighborhoods.
Stigma or limited providers make it harder to secure consistent care.
Rates continue climbing; youth obesity impacts schools and recreation.
Incidence trends upward; access to specialized care may be strained.
Job market is volatile with frequent booms and busts across major employers.
